reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central pillar of the essay’s case for “no easy eutopia”: the Section 3 claim that most plausible bounded/value-function forms are fussy, with only a narrow slice yielding easygoingness. If that modeling move were undermined, the paper’s systematic argument for broad fussiness would weaken a lot (though Section 2’s “many ways to fail” story could still support some version of the conclusion), hence moderate-high centrality. However, the critique mostly gestures at alternative axiological frameworks (lexical, pluralist, satisficing/sufficientarian, thresholding) and notes dependence on symmetry/normalization, without showing that these alternatives are (i) plausible under the essay’s own representability assumptions (completeness + VNM expected utility), (ii) actually avoid analogous forms of fussiness under realistic future distributions, or (iii) fit the essay’s definitions of ‘mostly-great’/‘near-best’ without reintroducing narrow targets. So it weakens but does not refute the attacked claims: moderate-low strength. The main points are broadly correct: the essay’s numerical ‘one part in 10^22’ illustration is sensitive to modeling choices, and the taxonomy of bounded views is not exhaustive; the critique’s named alternatives could in principle evade some of the paper’s specific failure modes, though some (e.g., lexical priorities) may conflict with VNM/continuity assumptions. Clarity is good but remains somewhat high-level. Little is pure fluff. It stays largely on one issue: oversimplification of axiological space/aggregation driving fussiness.
title: Pluralist and satisficing theories may avoid the paper's forced choice between fussiness and scale-tipping
